faq.title: Frequently Asked Questions
faq.subtitle: Find answers to common questions about blood donation

q1.question: How long does blood donation take?
q1.answer: The entire process takes about 45 minutes to an hour, including registration, health screening, and the actual donation. The blood collection itself only takes 10-15 minutes.

q2.question: Is blood donation safe?
q2.answer: Yes, blood donation is completely safe. All needles and equipment are sterile, single-use, and disposed of after each donation. You cannot contract any disease by donating blood.

q3.question: Will I feel weak after donating blood?
q3.answer: Most people feel fine after donating blood. Your body replaces the donated plasma within 24 hours and red blood cells within 4-6 weeks. We recommend resting for 10-15 minutes and drinking plenty of fluids.

q4.question: How often can I donate blood?
q4.answer: You can donate whole blood every 3 months (12 weeks). For platelet donation, you can donate every 2 weeks. It's important to allow your body adequate time to replenish.

q5.question: What should I do before donating blood?
q5.answer: Eat a healthy meal, drink plenty of water, get adequate sleep, and bring a valid ID. Avoid fatty foods before donation and inform staff of any medications you're taking.

q6.question: Can I donate if I have a tattoo?
q6.answer: Yes, you can donate blood if you got a tattoo more than 3 months ago from a licensed facility. This waiting period helps ensure safety.

q7.question: What happens to my donated blood?
q7.answer: Your donated blood is tested, processed, and separated into components (red cells, platelets, plasma). These components are then stored and distributed to hospitals where they save lives.

q8.question: Can I donate if I'm taking medication?
q8.answer: It depends on the medication. Most common medications don't prevent donation, but some may require a waiting period. Please consult with our medical staff during screening.

donationWorkflow.title: Donation Workflow
donationWorkflow.subtitle: Understanding the complete blood donation process from registration to component segregation

registration.heading: Registration and Donor History
registration.text: Prospective donors provide demographic information and complete a mandatory health questionnaire related to travel, medications, and medical history. This includes questions about recent illnesses, surgeries, vaccinations, and lifestyle factors that might affect blood safety.

vitalCheck.heading: Vital Check and Screening
vitalCheck.text: Healthcare professionals measure blood pressure, hemoglobin levels (minimum 12.5 g/dL for women, 13.0 g/dL for men), weight (minimum 50 kg), pulse rate, and body temperature to confirm donor eligibility. This ensures the safety of both donor and recipient.

counseling.heading: Counseling and Consent
counseling.text: Donors receive official guidance about the process, benefits, and potential risks, followed by signed consent that authorizes the collection. Counselors explain the importance of honest disclosure and answer any questions about the donation process.

instructions.heading: Pre-Donation Instructions
instructions.text: Donors are advised to have had adequate sleep, eaten a healthy meal, and consumed plenty of fluids before donation. They should avoid fatty foods and alcohol 24 hours prior to donation for optimal blood quality.

phlebotomy.heading: Phlebotomy Procedure
phlebotomy.text: A sterile needle is used to collect approximately 350 to 450 ml of whole blood under aseptic conditions. The collection site is thoroughly cleaned with antiseptic solution, and single-use sterile equipment ensures complete safety.

duration.heading: Duration and Monitoring
duration.text: The process typically takes 8 to 12 minutes, with medical supervision throughout. Trained staff monitor donors for any signs of discomfort or adverse reactions. Donors can squeeze a stress ball to improve blood flow during collection.

postCare.heading: Post-Donation Care
postCare.text: Donors are offered fluids and rest briefly to prevent dizziness. They receive recommendations to avoid heavy exercise and alcohol for the next 24 hours. Refreshments are provided, and donors are monitored for 10-15 minutes before leaving.

frequency.heading: Donation Frequency Guidelines
frequency.text: Whole blood can be donated every 56 days, platelets every 7 days, and plasma every 28 days. Maintaining proper intervals ensures donor health and blood quality.

transfusionSafety.heading: Testing for Transfusion Safety
transfusionSafety.text: Each unit undergoes screening for transmissible infections using advanced testing methods including ELISA and NAT (Nucleic Acid Testing). Tests include: HIV-1 and HIV-2, Hepatitis B (HBsAg) and Hepatitis C (Anti-HCV), Syphilis (VDRL/RPR), and Malaria. NAT testing can detect infections during the window period when antibodies are not yet detectable.

bloodGrouping.heading: Blood Grouping and Cross-Matching
bloodGrouping.text: Both ABO and Rh typing are performed using automated systems for accuracy. Compatibility testing ensures the safest match for the patient. Additional antibody screening is conducted to detect irregular antibodies that could cause transfusion reactions.

qualityControl.heading: Quality Control Measures
qualityControl.text: All testing equipment undergoes regular calibration and validation. Internal and external quality control samples are processed daily. Any reactive results are confirmed through repeat testing and alternative methods before deferring donors.

separation.heading: Separation Techniques
separation.text: The collected blood is centrifuged using refrigerated centrifuges at controlled speeds and temperatures to isolate life-saving components: Packed Red Blood Cells (stored at 2-6°C for up to 35-42 days, used for trauma and anemia cases), Platelets (stored at 20-24°C with constant agitation for 5 days, critical for cancer therapy and bleeding disorders), Fresh Frozen Plasma (frozen at -30°C or below within 6-8 hours, essential for liver disease and surgeries, valid for 1 year), and Cryoprecipitate (rich in clotting factors, used to treat hemophilia and clotting issues).

leukoreduction.heading: Leukoreduction Process
leukoreduction.text: White blood cells are removed through filtration to reduce the risk of febrile reactions, CMV transmission, and HLA alloimmunization. This process improves transfusion safety and is especially important for immunocompromised patients.

pathogenInactivation.heading: Pathogen Inactivation
pathogenInactivation.text: Advanced pathogen reduction technologies treat platelets and plasma to inactivate bacteria, viruses, and parasites while preserving therapeutic properties. This adds an extra layer of safety to the blood supply.

outcome.heading: Outcome
outcome.text: Through component therapy, a single donation can support up to three different patients, enhancing clinical impact. This approach maximizes the utility of each donation and ensures patients receive exactly what they need.

facilities.title: Blood Bank Facilities & Labs
facilities.subtitle: State-of-the-art infrastructure ensuring safe blood collection, testing, and storage

collection.title: Blood Collection Facilities
collection.description: Comfortable donation chairs, sterile equipment, and professional phlebotomists ensure a safe and convenient donation experience.
collection.details: Our donor centers are equipped with ergonomic donation chairs, individual privacy screens, and entertainment systems. Each station has dedicated emergency equipment, and the entire facility maintains strict temperature and hygiene controls. Phlebotomists are certified professionals with continuous training in donor care and adverse event management.

storage.title: Blood Storage & Preservation
storage.description: Temperature-controlled refrigerators and deep freezers ensure the correct storage conditions for all blood components.
storage.details: Our storage facilities include redundant cooling systems with 24/7 monitoring, backup power generators, and automated temperature logging. Each storage unit has alarm systems that alert staff to any temperature deviations. We maintain separate zones for quarantine, tested, and issued blood products to ensure traceability and prevent mix-ups.

pathology.title: Pathology & Serology Laboratories
pathology.description: Advanced analyzers conduct mandatory infectious disease screenings. Qualified lab technicians follow national and WHO safety standards.
pathology.details: Our serology lab is equipped with state-of-the-art automated analyzers for rapid and accurate testing. We perform both ELISA and NAT testing for all transmissible diseases. The lab maintains ISO 15189 accreditation and participates in external quality assessment schemes to ensure accuracy. Trained microbiologists oversee all testing procedures and result validation.

componentLab.title: Component Separation Laboratory
componentLab.description: Automated centrifugation systems and sterile transfer apparatus allow accurate separation of whole blood into components.
componentLab.details: The component lab operates under strict aseptic conditions with laminar flow hoods and HEPA-filtered environments. We use refrigerated high-speed centrifuges for optimal component separation. Automated blood processing systems ensure standardized procedures and reduce human error. All equipment undergoes regular calibration and maintenance.

qualityControl.title: Quality Control & Hemovigilance Unit
qualityControl.description: Routine quality assessments of each component. Traceability systems to monitor adverse reactions and maintain patient safety.
qualityControl.details: Our quality unit performs daily quality control testing on all blood components including pH, glucose levels, and sterility checks. We maintain a comprehensive hemovigilance system that tracks all donations from donor to recipient. Any adverse reactions are investigated, documented, and reported to regulatory authorities. Regular audits ensure compliance with national blood transfusion guidelines.

recovery.title: Donor Recovery & Counseling Room
recovery.description: Donors relax after donation under supervision and receive post-care guidance. Counselors address concerns related to diet, lifestyle, and repeat donation.
recovery.details: The recovery area provides a comfortable environment with refreshments, including juice, biscuits, and water. Donors are monitored for 10-15 minutes to ensure they feel well before leaving. Trained counselors are available to discuss any concerns and provide information about the donation process, what happens to donated blood, and when donors can give again. Emergency medical equipment and trained staff are always on standby.

bloodDiseases.title: Blood Diseases Awareness
bloodDiseases.subtitle: Understanding Thalassemia and other blood-related disorders

overview.title: Thalassemia: A Preventable Genetic Disorder
overview.description: Thalassemia is an inherited blood disease characterized by defective hemoglobin production, leading to severe anemia and organ complications.

major.title: Thalassemia Major
major.description: Symptoms appear early in childhood, requiring lifelong blood transfusions.
major.details: Children with Thalassemia Major typically show symptoms within the first two years of life. They experience severe anemia, requiring blood transfusions every 2-3 weeks to maintain hemoglobin levels. Without regular transfusions, patients develop serious complications including bone deformities, enlarged spleen, and stunted growth. The condition requires comprehensive medical management including regular monitoring, iron chelation therapy, and potential bone marrow transplantation.

minor.title: Thalassemia Minor (Trait)
minor.description: Individuals remain mostly asymptomatic but can pass the condition to children.
minor.details: Carriers of Thalassemia Minor lead normal, healthy lives with no symptoms or mild anemia. However, they carry one defective gene and can pass it to their children. If both parents are carriers, there's a 25% chance their child will have Thalassemia Major. Carrier detection through simple blood tests is crucial for family planning decisions.
